ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: If you decide to do the readings each week it may take one hour. There are three parts of a huge semester-long paper, each taking 10-15 hours to complete. HOWEVER, there is a huge group presentation that will take AT LEAST three full weekends if not more to complete.
5-15 depending on the time in the semester
one hour
The group project consumed most of our time - and probably deserved to be weighted more heavily than any other aspect of the course. On average it was probably 4 hours each week.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: By far the worst course I've taken at YSPH. I had really high expectations coming into this course because I always wanted to take a Betsy Bradley class. FALSE ADVERTISING to the extreme. Betsy taught ONLY five course sessions and the information is so basic, it was almost insulting. If you are a graduate student, take my advice and resist the temptation to take this course because you will learn absolutely nothing. And don't even get me started on the fact that this course is cross listed as a100 level course -- if this isn't a red flag, I don't know what is. This course contains 80% undergraduate students who's understanding of global health or public health is so minimal, their answers and questions will frustrate you all semester. Then, you will have to work with them for a huge presentation where you will never be able to find a common time for anyone to meet because MPH students and undergrads have NO common meeting times -- except on weekends and late evenings. There was also a completely useless and unnecessary section taught by a TA. Finally, there were many, many guest lecturers that were really terrible despite great credentials. In contrast, Barbara Bush (daughter of G.W. Bush) came and spoke and the instructors worshiped her as if she was actually qualified beyond her last name. PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE AT ANY EXPENSE IF YOU ARE AN MPH STUDENT.

A good class. Somewhat disorganized in structure. The policy presentation was a TON of work, but not worth a comparable amount of the grade. This should be changed. The presentation was the biggest assignment of the class but worth only a small amount. Also, the presentation was in between the writing of the paper. Made you forget about the paper entirely, and then had to go back and complete it. Would be better to have the WHOLE paper due before the presentation with ONE final version due at the end, or the WHOLE paper due after the presentations.Also, discussion sections were not useful and exercises were super juvenile. However, Rhobhi was a wonderful TA. Would be MUCH better to eliminate discussion section, but implement TA office hours in place.
I want a bit more global health so it doesn't just feel like a class on giving a good powerpoint.

Just a few suggestions:- the expectations of the course assignment were sometimes unclear- the section outside of class was a total waste of time for many students, and became a burden to attend. This aspect needs to be restructured in a way that is more meaningful and efficient.

I think the undergrads had the opportunity to learn a lot from the mixed classroom but that it was much less beneficial for grad students. Would have enjoyed the opportunity to scale work in the course.
Strength: interdisciplinary, guest speakers, strategic thinking

The strength of this class was definitely in the experience of the instructors. Each of them brought a different set of skills to the class, and that was useful in different ways.The in-class presentation was a very useful exercise as well, really making us think about the mechanics of presentation and coping under pressure.I would argue that the relative weights the presentation and final brief received in terms of the class grade did not represent proportionate amounts of work required. The demands of the presentation were higher than one could really justify for something worth such a small proportion of the overall grade.The class could be improved by tying the principles learned more closely to some of the in-class activities. Costing was a particular example of this, in which I never felt we really got to grips with how to do this properly, and so costing was something of a guessing game for both the final presentation and the brief.There was definitely some structural tension between the class wanting to be a seminar, with discussion, and also wanting to be a lecture course. I think this was one of the reasons why reading apparently wasn't always completed by allstudents.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Elizabeth Howe Bradley  Taught five class sessions
Instructor: Elizabeth Howe Bradley  Great!
Instructor: Elizabeth Howe Bradley  Always provided useful feedback to our projects.
Instructor: Elizabeth Howe Bradley  On point, sharp and critical (in a good way).
Instructor: Leslie Curry  Taught three, maybe four course sessions.
Instructor: Leslie Curry  Great
Instructor: Leslie Curry  Nice and ready to help.
Instructor: Leslie Curry  Excellent lecturer - kind and engaging with the class. Ready with advice.
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  Taught four course sessions. Has no business teaching at Yale due to zero research credentials. His former career was as a DC lobbyist.
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  Great
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  Nice and ready to help.
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  Really brought non-academic experience into the class in a useful way.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Wonderful TA, super helpful.
Rhobhi was great- very helpful
Nice and ready to help.
Rhobhi Matinyi: Hard-working, well-prepared. Suffered a little from lack from direction in some of the sections.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: 1) Cross listed as 100 level course (DO NOT take this if you are an MPH student)2) Contains 80% undergrads that you MUST work with3) Information is way too basic4) Betsy and Leslie Curry teach less than half of the sessions5) There is a pointless section session taught by a TA6) There is a giant presentation worth only 25% of your grate despite the fact you will exert 90% of your class effort preparing for it.
A good course especially for those in GH. Highly recommended, learned a lot.
Big YES. A great course to learn strategic thinking in global health arena.

Excellent course if you want to get a sense of how global health can be thought about at a macro policy level.Gives a good overview of advocacy at the Congressional level, as well as thinking more about details of implementation.
